siteMetadata.title: Autokin Automation
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using the Apollo GraphQL Client with React

frontmatter.title: Local state management
frontmatter.description: Learn how to store your local data in Apollo Client

children.value: We've learned how to manage remote data from our GraphQL server with Apollo Client, but what should we do with our local data? We want to be able to access boolean flags and device API results from multiple components in our app, but don't want to maintain a separate Redux or MobX store. Ideally, we would like the Apollo cache to be the single source of truth for all data in our client application.
, our solution for managing local data in Apollo Client, comes in.

allows you to store your local data inside the Apollo cache alongside your remote data. To access your local data, just query it with GraphQL. You can even request local and server data within the same query!
In this section, you'll learn how to simplify local state management in your app with
. We'll build client-side resolvers to help us execute local queries and mutations. You'll also learn how to query and update the cache with the
is already included in Apollo Boost, so you don't have to install it. It's configurable on the
property on the Apollo Boost constructor:
The three options you can pass to
The initial data you want to write to the Apollo cache when the client is initialized
A map of functions that your GraphQL queries and mutations call in order to read and write to the cache

A string representing your client-side schema written in [Schema Definition Language](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/graphql-tools/generate-schema.html#schema-language). This schema is not used for validation (yet!), but is used for introspection in Apollo DevTools
None of these options are required. If you don't specify anything, you will still be able to use the
If you'd like a deep dive into the
config properties, we recommend checking out the
. Otherwise, get ready to learn about these properties gradually as we build
If you'd like to follow along, please open our
on CodeSandbox. Since this example lives in the
repository, it does not use Apollo Boost for setup.
There are two ways to perform mutations in
. The first way is directly writing to the cache by calling
component. Direct writes are great for one-off mutations that don't depend on the data that's currently in the cache, such as writing a single value. The second way is creating a

component with a GraphQL mutation that calls a client-side resolver. We recommend using resolvers if your mutation depends on existing values in the cache, such as adding an item to a list or toggling a boolean. You can think of direct writes like calling
, whereas resolvers offer a bit more structure like Redux. Let's learn about both ways below!
Direct writes to the cache do not require a GraphQL mutation or a resolver function. They access your Apollo Client instance directly by accessing the
property within the render prop function of the

components. We recommend using this strategy for simple writes, such as writing a string, or one-off writes. It's important to note that direct writes are not implemented as GraphQL mutations under the hood, so you shouldn't include them in your schema. They also do not validate that the data you're writing to the cache is in the shape of valid GraphQL data. If either of these features are important to you, you should opt for a resolver instead.
Here's what a direct write looks like in our todo app with the
render prop function is called with a single value, the Apollo Client instance. You can think of the
. From the client instance, you can directly call
and pass in the data you'd like to write to the cache.
What if we want to immediately subscribe to the data we just wrote to the cache? Let's create an
property on the link that marks the link's filter as active if it's the same as the current
in the cache. To immediately subscribe to a client-side mutation, wrap it in a
component also has the client instance exposed on its render prop function.
// Remember to set an initial value for visibilityFilter with defaults
You'll notice in our query that we have an
field. This tells Apollo Client's network stack to fetch the query from the cache instead of sending it to our GraphQL server. Once you call
, the query result on the render prop function will automatically update. All cache writes and reads are synchronous, so you don't have to worry about loading state.

If you'd like to implement your local state update as a GraphQL mutation, then you'll need to specify a function in your resolver map. The resolver map is an object with resolver functions for each GraphQL object type. You can think of a GraphQL query or mutation as a tree of function calls for each field. These function calls resolve to data or another function call.
The signature of a resolver function is the exact same as resolver functions on the server built with
. Let's quickly recap the four parameters of a resolver function:
: The object containing the result returned from the resolver on the parent field or the
object in the case of a top-level query or mutation. Don't worry about this one too much for
: An object containing all of the arguments passed into the field. For example, if you called a mutation with

: The context object, which is shared between your React components and your Apollo Client network stack. The most important thing to note here is that we've added the Apollo cache to the context for you, so you can manipulate the cache with
: Information about the execution state of the query. You will probably never have to use this one.
Let's take a look at an example of a resolver where we toggle a todo's completed status:
In order to toggle the todo's completed status, we first need to query the cache to find out what the todo's current completed status is. We do this by reading a fragment from the cache with
. This function takes a fragment and an id, which corresponds to the todo item's cache key. We get the cache key by calling the
that's on the context and passing in the item's

Once we read the fragment, we toggle the todo's completed status and write the updated data back to the cache. Since we don't plan on using the mutation's return result in our UI, we return null since all GraphQL types are nullable by default.
Let's learn how to trigger our
First, we create a GraphQL mutation that takes the todo's id we want to toggle as its only argument. We indicate that this is a local mutation by marking the field with a
mutation resolver in order to resolve the field. Then, we create a
component just as we would for a remote mutation. Finally, pass in your GraphQL mutation to your component and trigger it from within the UI in your render prop function.
If you'd like to see an example of a local mutation adding a todo to a list, check out the
Querying the Apollo cache is similar to querying your GraphQL server. The only difference is that you add a
directive on your local fields to indicate they should be resolved from the cache. Let's look at an example:
First, we create our GraphQL query and add
. Then, we pass the query to our
component. Reading from the Apollo cache is synchronous, so you won't have to worry about tracking loading state.

Since the query runs as soon as the component is mounted, what do we do if there are no todos in the cache? We need to write an initial state to the cache before the query is run to prevent it from erroring out. That's where defaults come in!

object represents the initial state that you would like to write to the cache. It's important to provide defaults for your client-side queries, otherwise they could potentially error out if a mutation hasn't occurred before they run. The shape of your initial state should match how you plan to query it in your application.
Your defaults are written to the cache upon initialization of
before any operations have occurred. We also write them to the cache again if you reset the Apollo cache.
You can optionally pass a client-side schema to the
config property. This schema is not used for validation like it is on the server because the

modules for schema validation would dramatically increase your bundle size. Instead, your client-side schema is used for introspection in Apollo DevTools, where you can explore your schema in GraphiQL.
Your schema should be written in
. Let's view our schema for our todo app:
If you open up Apollo DevTools and click on the

tab, you'll be able to explore your client schema in the "Docs" section. This app doesn't have a remote schema, but if it did, you would be able to see your local queries and mutations alongside your remote ones. That's the cool part about
- it enables you to use GraphQL as a single, unified interface for all of your app's data.

properties.ariaLabel: combining local and remote data permalink

children.value: Whats really cool about using a
directive to specify client-side only fields is that you can actually combine local and remote data in one query. Since we don't have a remote server, let's look at an example from
where we add a client-only field to our remote data.
First, let's look at an example of a mixed query. The
field comes from the server. When the array of images comes back, we add a local field
We need to provide an initial state for
, our client-only field, but where do we put it? We can specify a resolver for
that will only be called the first time the image comes back from the server.
Now that we've specified an initial state in the form of a resolver, we can query the data as we normally would. If you would like to toggle the
field, you can create a mutation similar to the
mutation we created in a previous example.

Managing your local data with Apollo Client can simplify your state management code since the Apollo cache is your single source of truth for all data in your application. If you'd like to learn more about
: Dive deeper into the concepts we just learned, such as resolvers and mixed queries, by taking a look at the
: Read about our vision for the future of state management with GraphQL in the
: Check out this tutorial video by Sara Vieira if you'd like a step-by-step walkthrough on building an app with
